text: One battery expert told me he went to tech companies a decade ago and told them he could double the life of their devices, keeping stuff out of the landfill. "No one really cared," he said. "Extending product life wasn’t consistent with growth on the financial side."
author: AlanaSemuels

text: Remember when Apple launched the iPhone in 2007? Skeptics marveled at the company's aplomb, not allowing consumers to swap out batteries on their own. Now, that's the norm.
author: AlanaSemuels

text: Part of the problem is that lithium ion batteries degrade each time they're used. They're also volatile, which means companies make devices so that consumers can't swap them out easily.
author: AlanaSemuels

text:
AirPods' early adopters are finding their batteries no longer last very long. 

But there's no financial incentive for companies to make products that last a long time, because they won't sell as many.
